text: well good afternoon everybody and welcome to the Tuesday April the 9th
2019 session in our series about entrepreneurship and Asian high-tech industries
I'm Richard Dasher I direct the u.s. Asia Technology Management Center we're very proud to be presenting this series
in our 26th year of presenting these kinds of public seminars at Stanford I
would like to point out that the US Asia Center is a membership based industry
affiliates organization and so all of our support comes from member companies we have 5 member companies right now
about to be seven as soon as we get the next checks in and so we hope that
you'll get to meet the representatives of our companies some of whom are here today and we'll have some refreshments
outside thanks to their support and please stay around and get to know each
other and talk more about the session and do some Silicon Valley style networking so I'm happy to be able to
present what's really a yearly talk I give this Asia entrepreneurship update
every year as part of the series usually I give it in the first week but last
week as you know I was in Tokyo with Tim Romero who talked about the situation in Japan that should be up on video soon if
it is not already so make sure you try to find the type of that session if you
were not here in person yeah this is
going to be a weekly series will run through May the 28th this year you can
always find out more information on our website and what we're really trying to
do is to bring information and insights about entrepreneurship and the supporting ecosystems around the major
major economies of East Asia this is available for credit to Stanford
students but everyone is welcome if you're taking the course for credit make
sure you get a copy of the syllabus because the requirements for this seminar a
little bit unusual I asked each student to give me a weekly comment and I
usually reply directly to that weekly comment so it gives me a chance to
interact personally with every person that's taking the class but that's a little different from the way a lot of
seminars here work so be careful anyway where do you get started when you're
talking about Asia money's a good place so the total size of the world economy
world gross domestic product in 2018 was
estimated to be about 134 trillion dollars and the largest single country
economy in the world is China the US comes in at number two notice that there
are four Asia countries in the top ten
largest economies in the world and there are now nine Asia countries that are all
in what's called the trillion dollar Club now this is calculated at purchase
power parity if you use the real exchange rate you can get in a bank the
numbers would be very different this is calculated on what you can buy with a
particular amount of money or what how much money it takes to buy a particular basket of goods but it's a very good way
to compare economies to see what you can actually do from one to the next now one
reason Asia is so interesting is because of graphs like this this is the gross
domestic product of China this is the gross domestic product of the US was really about 2014 when China became the
world's single largest economy notice that India is doing very well India is
also growing at a rapid rate and Japan
and Germany kind of round out the top five countries in the world with what
you would call slow and steady I think the Japanese don't like it very
much I haven't heard too much complaining about growth rates from the Germans even though they're down around
you know 0.9 percent usually the Tigers
these used to be the jumping-off places to China the main reason to show this and so you get a sense of the relative
size South Korea is the biggest one in terms of the size of its economy and
then right after that you have Taiwan and you have Singapore and South Korea
and Hong Kong Special Administrative Region what most people are really not
expecting is the next slide in developing Asia if you look at the same
kind of growth pattern look at Indonesia people have really been missing the huge
amount of economic power that has been created in Indonesia over the years it's
the largest population of any of the Southeast Asian countries and it's by
far the largest economy now so when you have that kind of thing going on people
are always interested in what's coming ahead and one of the big sort of things
that people tend to look at more than these absolute numbers is the percentage of growth every year that an economy is
experiencing if you look at that and unfortunately they don't do that in PPP
so this is in real GDP calculations you see that the growth rate in China has
slowed down considerably you see a wide
variation in what's going on in India and you see this kind of you know the
world is cruising along at three point seven percent for the last four years or the last two years and it predicted to
stay about the same rate and yet all of these major economies from Asia are
growing a lot faster even as China slows it was about 10% a
year in as recently as 2014 or so 2012
down to what is predictably 6.2 percent this year 6.2 percent in an
economy the size of China in absolute terms is a much bigger amount of
economic output than you get with a much higher growth rate in a smaller economy
so this is one thing why China is still interesting to people even though it
slowed down but I think it's noticeable worth noting that the Chinese government
is definitely taking actions that I see as if not in response to they are
correlating with this slowdown there especially worried about the big infrastructure industries that really
grew up in the last generation in China consumer spending became the main driver
of the Chinese economy about seven or eight years ago but what happened all the infrastructure companies well we
have 150 billion dollars invested by the Chinese government in the belt and Road initiative so that this will actually
help those companies to expand to global markets as their own domestic market slows down we have a lot of
international investment going on by private sector Chinese firms we'll talk some more about that later in the
economy but I think rather than being something about innovation or
entrepreneurship that's global expansion this is a companies that are truly
becoming multinational corporations and that's a new thing for China we've seen
it in you know the Japanese and Korean companies for the last you know
somewhere between 50 and 20 years but to really have multinational companies in
China is kind of a new thing now as an
economy slows down though you expect more protectionism and China has not
opened up yet the Chinese market is very difficult for a lot of foreign firms to
get into you can't see facebook in China this will be put on YouTube but you will not see this on YouTube in China unless
you use some sort of a dodgy you know VPN that you might get in trouble for
and so there's a lot of things that are
unresolved about China I'm not going to get into that too much today but it's a real wild card we really don't know how
it's going to play out one thing you can see is that the patterns of growth that
are leading to these high economic growth patterns really reflect the new
spending patterns of an emerging middle class and this is characteristic not
only in China its characteristic especially in Southeast Asia now I was
in Thailand a couple of weeks ago and it was fascinating to see luxury items
right next to things that you wouldn't expect any other way we met the head of
line corporations subsidiary in Thailand and he pointed out that something like
two thirds of the 45 million people who have line accounts there are paying
their cellphones off every day they're buying minutes every day and he says if
you try to have a subscription-based service here it won't work so you know
there's a lot of things to think about how things are developing in these different countries India GDP growth is
noticeable but I'm seeing a polarization of India into really two different
systems you've got the world class information technology service providers
most of whom are making most of their money outside of India and you've got
the domestic economy where you have a lot of what's called frugal innovation you have a lot of things that are really
developing for the early stages of and a developing economy increasingly
this ecosystem in Asia is separate and distinct from the rest of what we're
used to it's not something with the United States as a hub anymore there are new
supply chains that are servicing these new Asia consumer markets and you know
in the middle of this China is really intentionally developing self-sufficiency across the board not
only is it investing in artificial intelligence but it's also investing a lot in the very basic components
computer chips and it's developing at the other end new kinds of automobiles
and they even actually be ahead of Western countries and autonomous driven
vehicles in a few years so you know Southeast Asia is no longer just the
beginning stages of a supply chain that ends up in the US or Japan or Europe
you're seeing an awful lot of cross-border expansion inside Asia after
the u.s. pulled out of the trans-pacific partnership it's been kept on as TPP
minus one and China has it's competing version of this free trade agreement
called the RCEP and you're also seeing the private
sector taking of doing a lot of things to expand across the region grab I
mentioned line visiting their Thailand offices go jack lazada these are our companies
that have successfully become multinational at least six or seven
different countries a lot in Southeast Asia so there's a lot of investment
going on cross-border inside Asia you're seeing unicorn creation across Asia I'll
talk a little bit more about that in the innovation section of the talk today
and Southeast Asia is the new battleground for influence you see it on
both sides the Chinese government is using this belt and road initiative it's
a way to project soft power and it's a way to help its own domestic industries
and it's a way to fulfill what it sees as its appropriate place in the world
order right now and you know a lot of the expansion going on by companies like
Alibaba and 10 cent are to reduce the influence of companies like Amazon in
other parts of the world so uber had to
sell it Southeast Asia business to grab but it did get some grab stock in there
as a result so it's not like it completely lost out of the deal Alibaba
has bought 83 percent of the Singapore
based electronic commerce company lazada that's in half a dozen different countries and it has also invested over
a billion dollars in tokopedia which was a competitor to lazada that's based in Indonesia Expedia has led group kind of
investment in tokopedia which is a travel site kind of like travel loca I'm
sorry not tokopedia travel oka which is a travel site kind of like Expedia is
itself and Amazon started its prime services in Singapore now in the middle
of this you're seeing a lot of books about New World Order Kai Fuli just wrote one about AI superpowers and he
points out that it's a different type of expansion being done by American firms
that are done by the Chinese firms the Chinese firms tend to look for more local partners and tend to work really
through their local partners more while the American firms tend to just export
their services over to the other country a lot of people in China thing
but their approach will be more successful one because there's a lot of
similarities in the purchasing behavior in the consumer behavior of this
emerging middle class in these different countries and it's rather different from the old-style middle class that you have
in the old advanced economies so another
thing that I think is going on in general in Asia right now is that
attention to social concerns is actually being turned from a problem into a huge
opportunity area so especially in Japan
and almost that much in South Korea and almost that much in China people are
really worried about the aging population so guess what there are hundreds of new companies that are being
created around you know things to make the situation better for people as they
get older you're seeing a lot of leapfrogging going on where even though the
infrastructure that we have in advanced economies has not been developed they
will allow people in these emerging economies to have the same kind of
services using their cell phone so mobile banking is probably is a lot
further ahead in that part of the world than it is here and you know you're seeing a lot of
attention being paid to the UN's sustainable development goals I can't
tell you how many executives I run into Japan who have a little SDG lapel pin
that they're wearing now another kind of driver is the shift to the digital
economy so even though you would think that there are not enough people who
know how to do AI programming or other kinds of software programming that would be a huge mistake people are very quick
to learn and you're seeing serious technology plays coming out of places
all across Asia but there is still a lot of variation in the Asian economies and to
understand the dynamics of what people see as their competitive advantage it's
worth looking at what the World Economic Forum calls the three stages of Economic
Development so what we used to talk about is early stage developing
economies they call factor driven economies typically in a factor driven
economy the per person GDP or income sum
whatever I mean the some people want to count income some people want to count GDP but it's below fifteen thousand
dollars a year and in that kind of a sitting this is this is the situation
where you're getting the first industrialization of the country socially people start to flock to the
cities hundreds of millions of people have moved into the cities in China over
the last twenty five years and that this is not stopping this means that the
business opportunities are everywhere so why do you take the trouble to develop
an advanced technology if you can make money with a simpler play this is why
people have kind of downplayed Chinese technology capabilities for too long the
business opportunities don't require it and so you know why take the extra risk
getting there first to the market is by far a much more important competitive
advantage the government role at this stage is really basic laws commercial
code proper ship you know bankruptcy all
of this kind of stuff happens in this stage the second stage is usually called
efficiency driven the first companies that have become successful during the first stage need to keep growing and you
will often have labour and capital shortages as a result
and so they tend to grow by globalization they will grow the domestic markets as much as they can and
then they'll take the same thing and go overseas we're seeing that in China now we saw it in Korea in the early nineteen
ninety nineteen 90s we saw it in Japan from late 1970s so this is a kind of
thing that is a natural part of economic development which means that the
opportunities are scaling up great quality operational efficiency and it's
really at this stage that governments get real serious about intellectual
property rights as long as foreigners own all the intellectual property no
country is really going to care about it that much but when you have domestic people who are having problems with
intellectual property infringement people get real serious real quick the number of patent infringement cases in
China is exploding and interestingly enough the foreigners who are bringing
court cases in China now actually have a slightly better success ratio than do
Chinese domestic companies maybe because they're used to fighting that fight but
in any case this is characteristic of the middle income level the middle kind
of stage of economic growth this can be a very dangerous stage it's been very
dangerous in Japan and in South Korea because it's been hard to get out of and
I think one reason is that you learn how to be successful globalizing your
company expanding your company with great quality with scaling up all of
those kinds of things require refining your business processes and being even
more strict in how you maintain them unfortunately for the next stage what
really matters is distinguishing yourself by having exactly right thing
for the market even before the market knows it wants it this is the innovation
driven stay the economy and companies kind of have to unlearn some of the things that they
learned during the second stage so wealth spreads throughout the population
parents don't really want their kids to grow up and become line workers in a factory even though one of the problems
for economic structure is that at the second stage of an economy there are a lot of really well-paying jobs that
don't require more than a high school education but people always give their kids a college education and so the kids
don't really want to deal with the old type of economy either at this stage the
real competitive advantages have to do with understanding risk and being able to accommodate risk not avoid it but be
able to deal with it in a very efficient way how to keep how to keep high growth
going so you know if you're a startup company that wants to change the world
and you have changed the world and become a big company how do you keep up that high rate of growth so that's what
happens in the innovation driven stage and it's at this stage that the government starts to really worry about
its startup sector of the economy we've seen that here in the early 1980s with
SBIR grants you're seeing it now with similar kinds of programs in lots of
Asian economies so if you look at what's going around at some of these Asian
economies per person GDP in China right now is about sixteen thousand eight
hundred dollars so it's clearly in the middle stage it's in that efficiency
driven stage and sure enough you're seeing the big Chinese companies globalize you're seeing a huge rise in
venture capital and you're seeing government support for R&D and really
national infrastructure development that is looking ahead to the next stage I
will give this crédit that it's very forward-looking to
try to develop this you know the capacity to be an innovation driven
economy instead of just making the money now and figuring it will happen later in
Japan it's an innovation driven economy and you're seeing the startup ecosystem
grow we talked about that last week but the big firms are still not able to
benefit from the system like they do here just as a minor data point exits by
startup companies in the United States that are backed by venture capital tend
to happen at a ten to one ratio ten companies exit by being bought by big
firms for every one company that exits by going IPO and so that's an indication
of how much the big companies are getting or trying to get value from the
startup sector same kind of situation in South Korea in fact I could really put
those two into one row of on this chart with India the per person GDP is still
$7,100 that's a huge difference from even what you see in places like
Indonesia now or other places and so you do have these kind of two distinct
systems that are growing up alongside each other some parts of India are very
advanced economy other parts of India are very much you know early-stage get their first kind of
factor driven economic development in Singapore Singapore has a per person GDP
that's a lot higher than the US average and is actually pretty close to the
Silicon Valley average Silicon Valley incomes were somewhere around ninety
five thousand to a hundred ten thousand depending on whether you live in San Francisco or down on the peninsula last
year so Singapore is really close to here and sure enough
the financing hub for that entire region in Indonesia you've got an efficiency
driven economy that is the largest domestic market in the region a lot of
infrastructure plays are still rolling out and a lot of big company plays are
happening in Singapore Singapore is also the location of four unicorns that were
created in the last ten years and and Indonesia was the location of four more
there's also one unicorn in Vietnam and one unicorn in one of the other
Southeast Asian countries sorry but in any case you see that most of Southeast
Asia tends to be at that level and that's the trigger level where you start
to see middle-class spending on things like automobiles things like televisions
and so yeah this is why it's exciting to a lot of people so let's get around to
entrepreneurship we've this was sort of general economic discussion slanted
toward entrepreneurship but I want to start out by talking about data that is
presented every year from a major consortium called the Global
Entrepreneurship monitor they do a survey of almost two hundred thousand
people worldwide every year now this is run out of Babson College which is
famous for study of entrepreneurship but they also have key partner universities
around the world and they use a local team in each country to do the surveying
we're going to look at their adult population survey which minimum size of
a good sample is 2,000 people and they will not report the results for a year
if they don't like the way the data was pulled so yeah
we're not going to use the second part of the survey which is a survey of experts asking them for they're really
kind of subjective opinions about the ecosystem in that particular country
this is the 20th year that Jim has been an operation and their online website is
a great place to go for data what I'm going to focus on is what they call the
total early stage entrepreneurial activity index also known as the T rate
and they've got a very clever definition for this because as you know there are a
lot of really small businesses in any economy that don't kind of fit the model
of startup we are talking about when we're studying entrepreneurship so what they do is in this tr-8 they include
people who are actively involved in setting up a business or people who are
managing a new business that have paid salaries for up to three and a half
years once you've paid salaries for more than three and a half years you fall out of the tier 8 so if you look at how tea
rates tend to run we talked about those three stages of an economy the tea rate
in general tends to drop as an economy becomes more advanced one reason is
because in a developing economy there are not as many salaried jobs in big
companies that people could have so more people are entrepreneurs because they have to be entrepreneurs
this is called necessity driven entrepreneurship if you divide it up
between men and women it's interesting that the tea rate actually jumps up a
little bit in the middle stage of the economy if you separate men and women
out that's very counterintuitive but
if you look at what's going on you're seeing that it's pretty close to the
sense of being necessity driven women who are necessity driven they have to be
an entrepreneur in order to eat right and it's not like they saw an
opportunity they want to seize there is no job available to them that they could take that's actually the greatest
participation is found at this middle stage of economic development so that's
the general trend in tea rates and economies the u.s. tea rate
sure enough shows what goes on in the general economy it dropped like a rock
around the time of the last recession and it's been going up steadily ever
since then so that we actually have a higher T rate in the United States than
people do in China so if you look at China the tea rates spiked in the year
2011 probably because of government official announcements supporting entrepreneurship and then it's kind of
been declining ever since then japan's tea rate is very low and if you look at
India India has had a kind of gradually may be declining tea rate it's kind of
hard to tell in general when you see a lot of yearly variation it means that the economy is in some sort of a state
of change means there's some sort of flux going on and maybe structural
changes is in the way if you look at the Tigers the jumping off places to China
you see consistently lower T rates than
the US right I kept the UST rate in gray so it for your reference but you see a gradual
sort of increase in the amount of entrepreneurship in the economy that
reflects a shift in the type of entrepreneurship that type of
motivation people have for entrepreneurship in the early stages it was driven by a necessity but in the
later stages of the more advanced stages of an economy is because people see the
best opportunities they don't want to just be earning a salary and not able to
exercise their creativity they see the possibility of making the world
different and so you see this kind of gradual increase over time since 2003
with Southeast Asia you start out where everybody except Malaysia had a has a

middle stage of an economy right twelve to sixteen thousand dollars a year of
GDP per person you see a lot of up and down which to me says there's some sort
of change going on or possibly some sort of a sensitivity to external factors
I didn't yeah I did put Thailand in here so Thailand even didn't even count 2010

I think that given the amazing rise in

fifty-four percent of non entrepreneurs saw or thought that they had the ability

everybody believes that opportunities for entrepreneurs are just fantastic
most of these numbers are relatively flat the actual tea rate the intention

there is pretty stable self-assessment of our abilities to be an entrepreneur

right most of them started in the last 20 years so this is you know this is the

first of all I mentioned this bump in 2011 zoom everything went up not only

what I really see in this graph I'm sure enough there was a year or two when they

because Thailand has the highest fear of failure rate we've seen well over 50

the base rate for entrepreneurship people who know Japan are extremely

and of course the fear of failure is high but it's not that high if you were

the huge barrier in Japan is that people
do not see much good opportunities to start the company and so that has to do
maybe with funding more likely it has to do with how hard it is to get a product
to market if you're doing a consumer play that's like an iPhone app it's not
that hard but if you're in the business to business world it's extremely hard to
get a big company in Japan to give you the time of day and so this is kind of
the situation of what's going on there but I don't want to be too negative last
week Tim I thought gave a very well thought-out description of what's going
on with the ecosystem around entrepreneurship in Japan and I don't
really have anything to take away from that but I want to kind of put it in context of the whole region so if you're
looking at an innovation system especially an entrepreneurial innovation
system you need to think about three elements you need to think about people you need to think about capital and you
need to think about ideas and knowledge if you want to have a robust system of
Vernor you not only have to have sources of those three elements you also
have to have dynamics that make it easy to flow into a new combination now this
applies inside a big company as well as in a startup company inside a big
company you've got to get a budget for your R&D project you have to do something with the intellectual property
that you create and you're going to get the basis for that something from
somewhere so it does apply in a big company too but it's really easy to see
inside a startup company inside a startup company the people will start by
using their own capital they'll use their own money to start the company off and they will have to have the ability
to use their own knowledge or ideas if I invent something at Stanford and it's
trying to start a company around it I have to buy the rights to my technology back from Stanford that means I need
capital and I also need to acquire the right to use that knowledge in order to
run my company so different kinds of things play into that model at the
different stages of company growth at the startup one of the main things to
focus on in an entrepreneurship ecosystem is the presence or absence of angel investors mainly as a source of
money with regard to people you not only have the founders but you have the
people who will mentor the founders that's a very important part of this
system and in regard to ideas and knowledge they need to have access to
are in the output Design Thinking is a technique that people use to come up
with new ideas not only technology knowledge but you also need market and
business knowledge you need to be able to get that somehow if you don't already have it and of course there's a need for
infrastructure both physical and for structure and legal infrastructure and also paid consultants who had never
really become part of your team but you may need to know what somebody will say
about your market opportunity an order to get money as the company gets started
and as the company is growing that's when venture capital funds come into play at the very late stages of
growth is where you get loans coming into play the key things for people at
that stage are not the entrepreneurs it's the people who are willing to go to work in a startup company and that has
been largely ignored by almost every government program trying to support
entrepreneurship in the world these are the people who are forgotten employee
number 15 right and it's at this stage that you see things like Lean Startup principles
and rapid prototyping it's also at this stage where investor relations becomes a
major thing that often leads to a company falling apart and you need to be
able to get to markets you need legal and accounting infrastructure and so forth at that stage to the exit stage is
also a critical part of the ecosystem are there opportunities to go IPO to be
bought by a big firm and once you do is
there a flexible labor market so that the people who are working your in your company actually see being in your
company as a positive step in their career including you yourself if you're
the entrepreneur in regards to the ideas
and knowledge side of things if a big company buys your firm does that mean that your idea has just been killed
sometimes big firms by smart startup companies with that intention but a lot
of times I just don't do a very good job of taking the idea on to its full potential
and finally you know you need bankruptcy law you need transparent accounting principles and so forth
for the companies to be sustainable after they've gone through that startup and growth phase so what's going on in
Asia well everywhere in the world companies start with friends and family
money I don't think that's anything unique anywhere and it's hard to get
friends and family money in every part of the world what's the real bottleneck in most Asian economies our angel
investors who have startup company experience Tim mentioned that very well
last week in Japan he said it's only been in the last couple of years that he's seen successful entrepreneurs turn
into angel investors up until that point they were you know people who did
personal investing in start-up companies where people who had a lot of money but
they didn't know the world of entrepreneurship venture capital
investments are the first thing that have really grown in Asia there are some slowdowns there's a downright flood of
venture capital money in China right now and yet you have to say that a lot of
